natural problem: It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip?
natural solution: Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed_uphill speed_downhill avg_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "speed_uphill = 1 / 0.5"
and h1 : "speed_downhill = 1 / 0.1667"
and h2 : "avg_speed = 2 / ((1/speed_uphill) + (1/speed_downhill))"
shows  "avg_speed = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes speed_uphill speed_downhill avg_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "speed_uphill = 1 / 0.5"
and h1 : "speed_downhill = 1 / 0.1667"
and h2 : "avg_speed = 2 / ((1/speed_uphill) + (1/speed_downhill))"
shows  "avg_speed = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A cyclist is traveling at a speed of 2 miles per minute uphill and at a speed of 6 miles per minute downhill. What is the cyclist's average speed for the entire trip, assuming the distance traveled uphill is equal to the distance traveled downhill? The final answer is 3 miles per minute.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes time_up time_down distance :: real
assumes h0 : "time_up = 30"
and h1 : "time_down = 10"
and h2 : "distance = 1"
shows  "(2 * distance) / ((time_up + time_down) / 60) = 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes time_up time_down distance :: real
assumes h0 : "time_up = 30"
and h1 : "time_down = 10"
and h2 : "distance = 1"
shows  "(2 * distance) / ((time_up + time_down) / 60) = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A person climbed a hill for 30 minutes and then descended for 10 minutes. The hill is 1 mile high. What was the average speed, in miles per hour, for the whole trip? The final answer is 3 miles per hour.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed_uphill speed_downhill speed_average :: real
assumes h0 : "speed_uphill = 1 / 0.5"
and h1 : "speed_downhill = 1 / (10 / 60)"
and h2 : "speed_average = 2 / ((1 / speed_uphill) + (1 / speed_downhill))"
shows  "speed_average = 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes speed_uphill speed_downhill speed_average :: real
assumes h0 : "speed_uphill = 1 / 0.5"
and h1 : "speed_downhill = 1 / (10 / 60)"
and h2 : "speed_average = 2 / ((1 / speed_uphill) + (1 / speed_downhill))"
shows  "speed_average = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: You are on a bike trip where you ascend a hill at a speed of 0.5 miles per hour and descend the same hill at a speed of 6 miles per hour. The average speed is calculated as twice the product of the two speeds divided by the sum of the two speeds. What is the average speed of the bike trip? The final answer is 3 miles per hour.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes d :: real and t1 t2 :: real
assumes h0 : "d = 1"
and h1 : "t1 = 30 / 60"
and h2 : "t2 = 10 / 60"
shows  "(2 * d) / (t1 + t2) = 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes d :: real and t1 t2 :: real
assumes h0 : "d = 1"
and h1 : "t1 = 30 / 60"
and h2 : "t2 = 10 / 60"
shows  "(2 * d) / (t1 + t2) = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If a distance of 1 unit is covered in 30 minutes for the first part and 10 minutes for the second part, what is the average speed (in units per minute) for the entire journey? The final answer is 3 units per minute.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance :: real
and time_uphill time_downhill :: real
and average_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "distance = 1"
and h1 : "time_uphill = 30 / 60"
and h2 : "time_downhill = 10 / 60"
and h3 : "average_speed = (2 * distance) / (time_uphill + time_downhill)"
shows  "average_speed = 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes distance :: real
and time_uphill time_downhill :: real
and average_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "distance = 1"
and h1 : "time_uphill = 30 / 60"
and h2 : "time_downhill = 10 / 60"
and h3 : "average_speed = (2 * distance) / (time_uphill + time_downhill)"
shows  "average_speed = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A cyclist travels a distance of 1 mile uphill and then 1 mile downhill. It takes 30 minutes to travel uphill and 10 minutes to travel downhill. Find the average speed of the cyclist for the entire journey. The final answer is 3 miles per hour.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes uphill_time downhill_time :: real
and uphill_distance downhill_distance :: real
and uphill_speed downhill_speed avg_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "uphill_time = 30"
and h1 : "downhill_time = 10"
and h2 : "uphill_distance = 1"
and h3 : "downhill_distance = 1"
and h4 : "uphill_speed = uphill_distance / (uphill_time / 60)"
and h5 : "downhill_speed = downhill_distance / (downhill_time / 60)"
and h6 : "avg_speed = 2 * uphill_distance / ((uphill_time + downhill_time) / 60)"
shows  "avg_speed = 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes uphill_time downhill_time :: real
and uphill_distance downhill_distance :: real
and uphill_speed downhill_speed avg_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "uphill_time = 30"
and h1 : "downhill_time = 10"
and h2 : "uphill_distance = 1"
and h3 : "downhill_distance = 1"
and h4 : "uphill_speed = uphill_distance / (uphill_time / 60)"
and h5 : "downhill_speed = downhill_distance / (downhill_time / 60)"
and h6 : "avg_speed = 2 * uphill_distance / ((uphill_time + downhill_time) / 60)"
shows  "avg_speed = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A cyclist travels uphill for 30 minutes, covering a distance of 1 mile, and then downhill for 10 minutes, also covering a distance of 1 mile. Calculate the average speed for the entire journey. The final answer is 3 miles per hour.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance :: real
and time_uphill time_downhill :: real
and speed_uphill speed_downhill :: real
and average_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "distance > 0"
and h1 : "distance = 1"
and h2 : "time_uphill = 30 / 60"
and h3 : "time_downhill = 10 / 60"
and h4 : "speed_uphill = distance / time_uphill"
and h5 : "speed_downhill = distance / time_downhill"
and h6 : "average_speed = (2 * distance) / (time_uphill + time_downhill)"
shows  "average_speed = 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes distance :: real
and time_uphill time_downhill :: real
and speed_uphill speed_downhill :: real
and average_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "distance > 0"
and h1 : "distance = 1"
and h2 : "time_uphill = 30 / 60"
and h3 : "time_downhill = 10 / 60"
and h4 : "speed_uphill = distance / time_uphill"
and h5 : "speed_downhill = distance / time_downhill"
and h6 : "average_speed = (2 * distance) / (time_uphill + time_downhill)"
shows  "average_speed = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A cyclist travels a distance of 1 mile uphill and then 1 mile downhill. It takes 30 minutes for the uphill ride and 10 minutes for the downhill ride. Determine the average speed of the entire trip in miles per hour. The final answer is 3 mph.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes d t_up t_down :: real
assumes h0 : "d = 1"
and h1 : "t_up = 1/2"
and h2 : "t_down = 1/6"
shows  "((2 * d) / (t_up + t_down)) = 3" (* average speed for round trip in km/hr *)
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes d t_up t_down :: real
assumes h0 : "d = 1"
and h1 : "t_up = 1/2"
and h2 : "t_down = 1/6"
shows  "((2 * d) / (t_up + t_down)) = 3" (* average speed for round trip in km/hr *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A person travels a distance of 1 km uphill at a speed of 2 km/hr and returns downhill at a speed of 6 km/hr. What is the average speed for the entire round trip? The final answer is 3 km/hr.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t1 t2 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 30 / 60"
and h1 : "t2 = 10 / 60"
and h2 : "t1 > 0"
and h3 : "t2 > 0"
shows  "harmonic_mean t1 t2 = 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t1 t2 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 30 / 60"
and h1 : "t2 = 10 / 60"
and h2 : "t1 > 0"
and h3 : "t2 > 0"
shows  "harmonic_mean t1 t2 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Calculate the harmonic mean of two times: 30 minutes and 10 minutes. The final answer is 3.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t1 t2 d1 d2 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 30 / 60"
and h1 : "t2 = 10 / 60"
and h2 : "d1 = 1"
and h3 : "d2 = 1"
shows  "((d1 + d2) / (t1 + t2)) = 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t1 t2 d1 d2 :: real
assumes h0 : "t1 = 30 / 60"
and h1 : "t2 = 10 / 60"
and h2 : "d1 = 1"
and h3 : "d2 = 1"
shows  "((d1 + d2) / (t1 + t2)) = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Two distances are covered in two separate times. The first distance is 1 mile and is covered in 30 minutes, while the second distance is also 1 mile and is covered in 10 minutes. Find the average speed for the entire journey in miles per hour. The final answer is 3 mph.
